Kent Beck wrote:

> Thank you for the feedback. We went around on this. It seems there are two
> cases:
> 
> 1) I am throwing an exception but I want to make it more specific so I throw
> a subclass (Exception -> IllegalArgumentException). No catch clauses care
> about the more-specific exception. If expected is looking for a precise
> class, a bunch of tests will break even though the code still works.
> 
> 2) The scenario you introduced--there are catch clauses in place that are
> looking for the more-specific exception. If expected is looking for any
> subclass of an exception class, the code might not work any more but the
> tests would pass.
> 
> Either way you're going to get false results. One question is which scenario
> is more common? Another is which scenario is more dangerous/risky/expensive?

I'm not Ben, but I'd like to add that whenever there are multiple 
exception handlers and the correspond caught exceptions are in one 
another's inheritance hierarchy, checking only the exception type caught 
is not necessarily a good idea in general. At that point, I strongly 
recommend checking the exception instance. It avoids this entire 
problem, in addition to being a stronger change detector.
